author: By Charles Homans
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Kick-Starts Campaign for Ohio Governor
description: The former presidential candidate is seeking the top office in his home state after a brief stint on President Trump’s cost-cutting task force alongside Elon Musk.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, the biotech entrepreneur and former Republican presidential candidate who briefly aided President Trump’s government-restructuring efforts, announced his candidacy for governor of Ohio on Monday, vowing to place the state at the forefront of a “second industrial revolution” in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Results from Germany’s election.
content: Voters in Germany yesterday threw their support behind centrist conservatives with the far right in second place, a sharp rebuke to the nation’s left-leaning government amid unhappiness about immigration and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima AbdulKarim and Erika Solomon
title: Why Tensions Are Rising in the West Bank
description: Amid the most intensive Israeli operations in the area in decades, Palestinians fear entrenched displacement and a return to military control in some towns.
content: Israeli operations against militants in the West Bank have escalated to a level not seen since the Second Intifada of the early 2000s. Tens of thousands have been forced to flee their homes, with Israel’s defense minister saying they will not be allowed to return. And for the first time in two decades, Israeli forces have sent tanks into the city of Jenin and established a military post in another, Tulkarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis Talks Up Wife as Potential Successor, Clashing With Trump
description: Far from tamping down chatter that Casey DeSantis could run for governor of Florida, Gov. Ron DeSantis praised her popularity and “intestinal fortitude.”
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said on Monday that his wife, Casey DeSantis, would be a formidable candidate if she chose to run for governor next year, a provocative suggestion that came days after President Trump endorsed Representative Byron Donalds as his preferred Republican candidate for the 2026 governor’s race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Just Like a Restaurant Dish (in the Best Way)
description: A layered, satisfying broccoli dish that’s creamy, crispy and tender all at once.
content: This is Tejal, filling in for Melissa Clark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I, Human
description: We know who we are, at least in part, by finding the words — messy, imprecise, unexpected — to tell others, and ourselves, how we see the world.
content: It was dark outside, a late afternoon in the fall of 1986. As I did each week during my last year of graduate school, I was sitting with my thesis director, the poet James Dickey. Campus was lively with classes convening and dismissing, but the darkness pooling outside made me feel we were isolated, marooned together in a place where words were life-or-death matters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli
title: How RZA Got Wu-Tang Clan Back Together for One Final Tour
description: The pathbreaking New York rap group, which has rarely performed as a full unit, is hitting the road for the last time.
content: Few groups have had more impact on the shape and evolution of hip-hop than Wu-Tang Clan, the Staten Island supergroup that helped define the sound of 1990s New York rap and transform the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root and Jan Ransom
title: Inmate Dies at N.Y. Prison as Corrections Officers’ Strike Continues
description: The 61-year-old man was found unresponsive in his cell at Auburn Correctional Facility, one of dozens of state prisons where corrections officers have walked off the job over working conditions.
content: An inmate at a New York State prison was pronounced dead on Saturday after being found unresponsive in his cell, state officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Alvin F. Poussaint, Pioneering Expert on Black Mental Health, Dies at 90
description: A psychiatrist at Harvard and an adviser to Jesse Jackson and Bill Cosby, he challenged Black Americans to stand up to systemic racism.
content: Alvin F. Poussaint, a psychiatrist who, after providing medical care to the civil rights movement in 1960s Mississippi, went on to play a leading role in debates about Black culture and politics in the 1980s and ’90s through his research on the effects of racism on Black mental health, died on Monday at his home in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Hawaii Man Wrongfully Convicted of Murder Is Freed After 30 Years
description: Gordon Cordeiro, 51, who was serving a life sentence for a 1994 murder on Maui, was released on Friday after DNA evidence was presented in his case.
content: A Hawaii man who spent more than 30 years behind bars for a murder he had long insisted he did not commit, was released on Friday on the orders of a judge who cited new evidence in his case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Buck
title: What Republicans Can Do to Take Control of DOGE
description: Congress has been ceding power to the president for decades. In the DOGE era, Congress needs to reclaim and use the tool of authorization.
content: Many Republicans in Congress loved what they were seeing: a leader willing to carve out waste and provide real scrutiny of a federal bureaucracy that has become too big, too liberal and too unaccountable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne
title: Three Years Into War in Ukraine, Trump Ushers In New World for Putin
description: Fresh possibilities have emerged for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with a change of power in Washington.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took the stage in Sochi, Russia, last fall, two days after Donald J. Trump won the U.S. presidential election, and spoke of the dawn of a new world order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Stodola
title: Your Resort’s ‘Perfect’ Beach Is a Lie
description: White sand, coconut palms, a gently sloping strand? That idea of tropical paradise is often manufactured. Resorts around the world are now embracing beaches in their more natural states.
content: Let’s buck the trend, a local marine biologist suggested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 625
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Paul Sonne
title: ‘We’re Your True Friends,’ Xi Tells Putin, as Trump Courts Russia
description: The Chinese and Russian leaders reaffirmed their relationship in a video call on Monday, an apparent rebuff to the idea that the Trump administration could drive a wedge between them.
content: China’s leader said his country and Russia were “true friends who have been through thick and thin together” after a video call with President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday, part of a pointed mutual affirmation of allegiance between Beijing and Moscow as President Trump has turned toward the Kremlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Susanne Craig
title: Dr. Oz: How His Millions Collide With Medicare
description: The TV celebrity and Trump nominee has pledged to divest from most of his financial interests. But they touch nearly every corner of health care, from insurance to blood pressure cuffs and vitamins, leading experts and lawmakers to doubt he could make impartial decisions.
content: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the celebrity TV doctor nominated by President Trump to oversee Medicare and Medicaid, has been a relentless promoter of controversial private insurance plans for older Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Catholics Around the Globe Pray for Francis at Sunday Mass
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 24, 2025.
content: “When I pray for my family at night, I include Pope Francis in my prayers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Miglore
title: How Long Can Yogurt Sit Out? And More Food Safety Questions, Answered
description: Your favorite breakfast staple is surprisingly long-lasting.
content: Yogurt was born as a means of preserving fresh milk, thousands of years before refrigerators were invented. But forget stashing a tub in your backpack or on the counter. The United States Department of Health and Human Services suggests throwing it out after two hours, the same deadline it gives fresh milk and other perishables. Why? And what are the true risks?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Manhattan Hotel Shelter That Became Symbol of Migrant Crisis Will Close
description: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Monday that the hotel will stop housing migrants by June, calling the closure a milestone in New York City’s response to the crisis.
content: The Roosevelt Hotel, a century-old building in the heart of Midtown Manhattan, became the improbable symbol of New York City’s migrant crisis, nicknamed “the new Ellis Island” for its role as an arrival center for migrants seeking shelter in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Julie Turkewitz, Hamed Aleaziz, Carlos Prieto, Shannon M. Lin, Will Reid, Alex Stern, Maria Byrne, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: Exporting America’s Immigration Problem
description: The Trump administration has asked Panama to take in hundreds of people who cannot easily be sent back to their home countries.
content: Warning: This episode contains mentions of suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Why American Businesses Aren’t Raring to Get Back Into Russia
description: The White House promised “incredible opportunities” if Moscow ended the war in Ukraine. But Russia’s economy is struggling and the business environment is unpredictable.
content: The Trump administration is sending a startling message to corporate America: After three years as an international pariah, Russia could once again be open for business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Starbucks to Lay Off 1,100 Corporate Employees Amid Sluggish Sales
description: The jobs cuts, which will affect about 7 percent of the chain’s non-retail staff, are part of its new chief executive’s plan to win back customers.
content: Starbucks is laying off 1,100 corporate employees, its chief executive said in a letter to workers on Monday, marking the coffee chain’s latest move to restructure amid lackluster sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: How Friedrich Merz Will Try to Lead Europe Despite a Weakened Hand
description: The likely next chancellor is unpopular, and his country’s economy has stalled. But his penchant for risks could help lead to a European showdown with President Trump.
content: Germany’s presumptive next chancellor could be weak from the start, for all sorts of reasons. He didn’t win a particularly high share of votes. Most Germans don’t think he’ll make a great leader. Many of the people who backed his party in Sunday’s elections say they’re not enthused with him, personally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Two Members of Privacy Watchdog, Summarily Fired by Trump, File Lawsuit
description: The case joins a rising number of legal challenges to President Trump’s firing spree that has violated limits on his power.
content: Two former members of an independent civil liberties watchdog agency who were fired by President Trump sued the government on Monday, asking a court to declare their terminations illegal and reinstate them to their former positions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Federal Judge Bars Elon Musk’s Team From Student Loan Databases
description: The American Federation of Teachers, a union representing more than 1.8 million educators, had sued to keep members of Mr. Musk’s government efficiency team out of the Education Department’s systems.
content: A federal judge in Maryland granted a temporary restraining order on Monday blocking the Education Department and the Office of Personnel Management from disclosing sensitive data to members of Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency team and anyone assisting them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ludovic Hunter-Tilney
title: 100 Years Ago Recording Studios Got a New Tool: Microphones
description: On Feb. 25, 1925, Art Gillham’s session made history. The technology changed who was heard in recordings, how artists approach their music and how we hear it.
content: One of the most significant innovations in recorded music took place a century ago in New York City. On Feb. 25, 1925, Art Gillham, a musician known as “the Whispering Pianist” for his gentle croon, entered Columbia Phonograph Company’s studio to test out a newly installed electrical system. Its totem was positioned in front of him, level with his mouth: a microphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Human Therapists Prepare for Battle Against A.I. Pretenders
description: Chatbots posing as therapists may encourage users to commit harmful acts, the nation’s largest psychological organization warned federal regulators.
content: The nation’s largest association of psychologists this month warned federal regulators that A.I. chatbots “masquerading” as therapists, but programmed to reinforce, rather than to challenge, a user’s thinking, could drive vulnerable people to harm themselves or others.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 24, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 24, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What’s Your Exercise Routine?
description: What can you learn about fitness from four cultures that make it a part of daily life?
content: What do you do to stay fit? Do you jog? Hit the gym? Start the day with stretching, push-ups or yoga? Go for walks or runs? Play sports?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Parade of Planets Is Marching Through the Night Sky
description: With Mercury joining the show, all seven of Earth’s celestial neighbors will be present at dusk this week.
content: Astute skywatchers may have already seen the striking line of planets across the night sky in January. This week Mercury joins the queue. Now every other world in our solar system will be visible among the stars at the same time — if you know where to look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump and Macron Display Old Friendship but Split on the Ukraine War
description: At a meeting at the White House, President Trump declined to call President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a dictator while President Emmanuel Macron of France stated flatly that “the aggressor is Russia.”
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Mogg
title: Can Supplements Actually Boost Your Immune System?
description: We asked experts about whether they have real benefits.
content: While perusing the supplement aisle, you’ll likely pass bottles of pills and gummies claiming to boost your immune system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Carol Rosenberg
title: Trump Administration Moves More Migrants to Guantánamo Bay
description: The base had been cleared of migrants since Thursday, after the government sent 177 to Venezuela and one back to the United States.
content: The military transported 17 immigration detainees from Texas to the U.S. base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on Sunday, bringing in new  migrants who have been designated for deportation days after it cleared the base of its first group of deportees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Devlin Barrett
title: Right-Wing Commentator Named F.B.I. Deputy Director
description: The choice of Dan Bongino is a radical departure from the bureau’s history of having a veteran agent serve in the key role that oversees operations.
content: Dan Bongino, a former New York City police officer and Secret Service agent turned right-wing pundit and podcaster, will be the next deputy director of the F.B.I., President Trump said on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 14 Unforgettable Looks at the SAG Awards
description: Angelic gowns, ‘Zoolander’ suits, pleated skirts and more.
content: It has been a busy weekend in Hollywood. On Saturday, stars paraded down carpets at the Film Independent Spirit Awards and the N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards. Less than 24 hours later, they were at it again for the 31st Screen Actors Guild Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump and Europe Clashed Over Ukraine
description: Also, the virtuoso Roberta Flack died at 88. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: President Trump and France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, repeatedly exchanged compliments and friendly gestures during a White House meeting this afternoon. But on the topic of Ukraine, the divergence between the two leaders was evident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Roberta Flack’s 11 Essential Songs
description: One of the supreme voices of the 1970s and a master of revelatory reinterpretation has died at 88.
content: At a New York concert in 1997, Roberta Flack referred to her voice as a “blessed instrument.” For generations of listeners it was just that, a spellbinding force that could be cool, or luxurious, or swell with suggestive power, often in the same song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: What Germany’s Election Result Means for Its Economy
description: The next German government faces calls to loosen borrowing rules, slash energy costs and spur innovation. It won’t be easy.
content: Friedrich Merz and his center-right Christian Democrats emerged victorious in Germany’s election on Sunday, but the celebrations may be short. The next government, almost certainly led by Mr. Merz as chancellor, faces a stagnant economy, President Trump’s threat to put tariffs on the country’s crucial export industries and a fourth year of war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Lynne Marie Stewart, Miss Yvonne on ‘Pee-wee’s Playhouse,’ Dies at 78
description: She was the “most beautiful woman in Puppetland” in the 1980s children’s show starring Paul Reubens, and more recently had a recurring role in “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.”
content: Lynne Marie Stewart, who played Pee-wee Herman’s perky, bouffant-wigged neighbor, Miss Yvonne, on the 1980s children’s television series “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” and the sweet, timorous mother of one of the main characters on “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Gina Kolata
title: Pope’s Condition Shows Slight Improvement, Stays Critical, Vatican Says
description: Francis is being treated for pneumonia, a complex infection and kidney problems that have left him in critical condition. He did some light work on Monday.
content: Pope Francis showed slight improvement on Monday, the Vatican said, adding that the pontiff’s condition remained critical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Jason Horowitz
title: Francis Is in Critical Condition. What Happens When a Pope Dies?
description: Time-honored rituals, drafted and refined over centuries, allow time for mourning and provide order at a dramatic moment of transition.
content: The Catholic world is gripped with uncertainty as Pope Francis, 88, remains in critical condition in a Rome hospital because of a complex lung infection and other serious ailments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Judge Blocks Immigration Raids in Certain Places of Worship
description: Religious organizations are challenging a Trump administration policy that allows ICE to conduct operations in sensitive locations. The judge declined to pause the policy more broadly.
content: A group of mostly Quaker religious organizations has succeeded in temporarily preventing federal immigration agents from operating around their places of worship across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Jen Psaki Gets Nightly Prime-Time Show at MSNBC
description: The change is part of a broad shake-up at the network, including the cancellation of Joy Reid’s program.
content: MSNBC said on Monday that Jen Psaki, the former White House press secretary who has become one of the most prominent hosts at the network, would anchor a nightly weekday show in prime time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Clint Hill, Who Sprang to Kennedys’ Side as Shots Were Fired, Dies at 93
description: A Secret Service agent, he leaped onto the president’s limousine in Dallas in 1963 and was credited with saving the first lady’s life. But he was haunted by his inability to save her husband.
content: Clint Hill, the Secret Service agent who leaped onto President John F. Kennedy’s limousine as it came under fire in Dallas and prevented a scrambling Jacqueline Kennedy from falling to the ground, died on Friday at his home in Belvedere, Calif. Mr. Hill, hailed for his bravery but long tormented by his inability to save the president’s life, was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Questions Constitutionality of Musk’s Cost-Cutting Operation
description: The judge expressed concern over the unresolved issues about who is in charge of Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency, if it is not Mr. Musk, as the White House has claimed.
content: A federal judge in Washington said on Monday that the way the Trump administration set up and has been running Elon Musk’s so-called Department of Government Efficiency may violate the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: Federal Judge Shields More Transgender Inmates From Trump Order
description: A group of transgender women in federal prisons who would have been moved into men’s facilities can stay where they are for now.
content: A federal judge on Monday shielded more transgender women housed in federal prisons from an executive order that would have transferred them from all-female to all-male units and ended their hormone treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Olivia Bensimon
title: Crypto Firm Pleads Guilty to Operating Illegally in U.S.
description: Federal prosecutors said OKX, based in Seychelles, violated anti-money laundering laws for years. The company agreed to pay more than $500 million in fines and penalties.
content: An offshore cryptocurrency trading firm pleaded guilty on Monday in U.S. District Court in Manhattan to a charge of operating as an unlicensed money transmitting business in the United States while seeking customers in New York and other states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Banty, Blustering Genius of Earl Weaver
description: The famous Baltimore Orioles manager gets a vivid new biography, the book equivalent of “a screaming triple into the left field corner.”
content: The greatest sight in Major League Baseball during the 1970s was almost certainly this one: the Baltimore Orioles manager Earl Weaver storming out of the dugout to remonstrate over some perceived injustice to his players. He would be so incensed at the officiating — or he pretended to be — that it was if he’d been eating chilies and was excreting flames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Kenyan Police Officer Killed in Haiti in Anti-Gang Operation
description: The officer’s death appeared to be the first among the Kenyan forces that were sent to Haiti last year as part of an international effort to subdue gang violence.
content: A Kenyan police officer was shot and killed in Haiti on Sunday in an operation that was part of the international effort to help combat gang violence and restore order to the Caribbean nation, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thasunda Brown Duckett
title: Pensions Aren’t the Only Way to a Secure Retirement
description: Americans need to pay more attention to making sure the money they’ve saved will last through retirement.
content: Americans are increasingly concerned that it’s harder to secure the things that once represented economic progress and achievement — homeownership, a college education, a well-paying job and a decent retirement. This economic uncertainty is making many feel left out and left behind. People are casting a wide net for solutions, and policymakers should be ready with big, creative, new ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Dangles Rare Earths Deals for U.S. in Russia and Occupied Ukraine
description: In an interview broadcast on Monday, President Vladimir Putin said U.S. companies stood to profit in Russia, but suggested a Ukraine peace deal was still far off.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday said American companies could do lucrative business deals in Russia and even help mine rare earths in Russian-occupied Ukraine, further amplifying the Kremlin’s message to President Trump that there was money to be made from a better relationship with Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Jane Fonda Says ‘Empathy Is Not Weak or Woke’ at the SAG Awards
description: While some stars have been less politically outspoken this awards season, she issued a call to action as she accepted a lifetime achievement award from the Screen Actors Guild.
content: Jane Fonda, who has been politically outspoken since the Vietnam War era, urged people “to resist successfully what is coming at us” as she accepted a lifetime achievement award Sunday night during the Screen Actors Guild Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Edmund Lee and Grady McGregor
title: Defying DOGE
description: Pushback against Elon Musk’s latest demand to government employees reveals potential limits to his harsh approach to management and cost-cutting.
content: Monday could bring a standoff between Elon Musk and huge swaths of the federal government, including Trump-appointed agency leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles W. McFarlane
title: Oh, This Old, Tattered, Moth-Eaten Thing?
description: So-called thrashed clothes — garments resembling something closer to rags — are coveted by vintage fanatics.
content: When Abe Lange lived in the East Village of Manhattan, he would sometimes take his breakfast in Tompkins Square Park, wearing his favorite zip-up hoodie. You might say it had seen better days: The black jersey had faded to a charcoal ombré, and large portions of the front and sleeves had worn away, revealing the inner thermal lining.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Gaza Truce Could End in Days, With No Extension Agreed. What Happens Next?
description: Less than a week before it expires, Israel and Hamas have failed to agree to extend the cease-fire in Gaza. Here’s how the deal could still continue — and what happens if it doesn’t.
content: When Israel and Hamas agreed to a six-week cease-fire in January, there were hopes that it would evolve into a longer and more stable truce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Protesters Display Upside-Down American Flag at Yosemite
description: Organizers said the inverted flag, historically used as a sign of distress, was meant to draw attention to the Trump administration’s cuts to the National Park Service.
content: A small group of protesters hung an inverted American flag — historically used as a sign of distress — off the side of El Capitan, a towering rock formation in Yosemite National Park, on Saturday, hoping to draw attention to the Trump administration’s cuts to the National Park Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Nears a Deal to Give U.S. a Share of Its Mineral Wealth
description: President Trump said that Ukraine’s president may soon visit the White House to sign a deal, though how it ties in to efforts to end the Russian invasion and guarantee Ukraine’s security is unclear.
content: Ukraine and the United States are closing in on an agreement that would grant Washington a share of Kyiv’s revenues from natural resources, President Trump and a Ukrainian government official said Monday, after an intense pressure campaign from the American president to strike a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.S. and European Allies Split Sharply at the U.N. Over Ukraine
description: The United States opposed a resolution demanding Russian withdrawal from Ukraine, but won Security Council approval of one calling for peace without assigning blame, exposing fissures between allies.
content: A showdown over Ukraine between the United States and its longtime European allies played out in the United Nations on Monday, as the United States opposed an effort to condemn Russian aggression and call for the immediate withdrawal of Russian forces from Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Ashley Southall
title: For Savvy New Yorkers, It’s All About Cheap Eggs and Where to Find Them
description: A bird flu outbreak affecting eggs hits differently in a city where prices and availability fluctuate from block to block.
content: The inquiries start casually. “Hey, I haven’t seen you in a while. How have you been?” But when Alex LaMond’s phone lights up with texts from her Brooklyn neighbors, she knows what’s coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Lester Holt to Step Down as Anchor of ‘NBC Nightly News’
description: The longtime newscaster said he would leave the daily news show at the “start of summer.” NBC did not immediately name a successor.
content: Lester Holt, the veteran NBC newscaster and anchor of the “NBC Nightly News” over the last decade, announced on Monday that he will step down from the flagship evening newscast in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Reinstates Fired Medical Device, Food and Legal Staffers
description: The agency changed course just days after firing employees who oversee the safety of food and life-sustaining medical devices. Dozens of workers said they and others were back at work Monday.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has reinstated dozens of specialized employees involved in food safety, review of medical devices and other areas who were laid off last week, according to more than a dozen workers who got called back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Institute Asks Judge in Trump Documents Case to Disclose Special Counsel Report
description: The report is the second volume of a report Jack Smith wrote after dropping the federal criminal cases he brought against Donald J. Trump because of his 2024 election victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fair or Not, Zelensky Is Angering Trump. Is His Style Hurting Ukraine?
description: Through three years of wartime leadership, Ukraine’s president has mostly played weak hands wisely. But his approach has fallen flat with the Trump administration.
content: When the secretary of the treasury, Scott Bessent, traveled to Kyiv this month, he wanted President Volodymyr Zelensky to sign an agreement ceding mineral rights to the United States, delivering a quick win for the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller and Photographs by Damon Winter
title: Sequins, Merch, Chain Saws: Trump’s Return to CPAC
description: Inside the pro-Trump scene at the yearly conference.
content: The first month of President Trump’s return to office has been very intense. Onstage at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC), the annual gathering of conservative activists, the speakers talked about the chaotic energy there as a great thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: Who Was That Masked Man?
description: There are no answers this week — or even hints — to the identity of the dead body in the season premiere, but we do see a robbery.
content: “The White Lotus” has always been a show that centers sensuality, and so far in Season 3, the creator, Mike White, has amplified that dreamy, loopy, intoxicated feeling. In this week’s episode, in a sequence set during the resort’s dinner service, the guests — and we, the viewers — are blitzed with distractions. There are musicians, dancers and acrobats serving as mealtime entertainment, and bursts of flame rising from the table-side food prep. The characters, meanwhile, are still jet-lagged and coping with culture shock — not to mention a little tipsy. (Hey, it’s vacation.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Kate Conger
title: Trump Administration, Breaking With Musk’s Directive, Says Replying to His Email Is Voluntary
description: The response to Elon Musk’s “What did you do last week?” email to federal employees suggests that there may be limits to how far he can push the government’s work force.
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French, Kori Schake and Vishakha Darbha
title: Trump’s Bargain With Putin Is ‘Shameful’
description: Turning our back on Ukraine would only weaken America.
content: The Trump administration may be considering negotiating a peace deal with Russia that would end the war in Ukraine. “No American president in the last 80 years and probably 100 years before that would have made this bargain,” Kori Schake, the director of foreign and defense policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, tells the Opinion columnist David French.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: A Rising Star Rides the Stormy Seas in a Maritime ‘Hamlet’
description: Luke Thallon expertly blends sincerity and neediness as the embattled prince in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s latest production.
content: In the Royal Shakespeare Company’s new “Hamlet,” the Danish royal court is all at sea — quite literally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drake Returns to No. 1 With PartyNextDoor
description: Their collaborative album “Some Sexy Songs 4 U” opens atop the Billboard 200, unseating his foe Kendrick Lamar’s “GNX,” which surged after the Super Bowl halftime show.
content: News flash: Drake’s music is not dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and Winnie Hu
title: Congestion Pricing Reduced Traffic. Now It’s Hitting Revenue Goals.
description: Revenue figures from the Manhattan tolling plan showed that the program is on track to raise billions for mass transit repairs.
content: New York’s congestion pricing plan raised $48.6 million in tolls during its first month, a strong start for the program that exceeded expectations and kept it on track to raise billions of dollars for the region’s decaying mass transit system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: SAG Awards 2025: ‘Conclave’ Comes on Strong
description: The thriller about choosing a new pope took home the top film prize, while Demi Moore and Timothée Chalamet won individual honors.
content: The papal thriller “Conclave” won the top prize at the 31st Screen Actors Guild Awards on Sunday night, thwarting a guild sweep by “Anora,” which had previously scored big wins earlier this month at ceremonies thrown by the producers, directors and writers guilds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Stefanik’s Confirmation Is on Ice as Republicans Guard Their Scant Majority
description: The congresswoman from New York is in line to be confirmed as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. But first, her colleagues need her vote to pass their embattled budget plan.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson revealed on Monday why Representative Elise Stefanik of New York has yet to have her confirmation vote to serve as ambassador to the United Nations: He cannot afford to lose another Republican vote in the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Frank G. Wisner, Diplomat With Impact on Foreign Policy, Dies at 86
description: He headed U.S. embassies around the world and relished the role, bringing a gregarious style to promoting American interests. But he clashed with the Obama White House.
content: Frank G. Wisner II, a veteran American diplomat, Washington insider and foreign affairs specialist who relished the prestige of ambassadorial life as much as the back-channel cajoling and arm-twisting of less public influence, died on Monday at his home in Mill Neck, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 86.His son, David, said the cause was complications of lung cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Husband and Wife, Both in 70s, Are Arrested by Afghan Taliban
description: Peter and Barbie Reynolds were arrested on Feb. 1, their children told U.K. news outlets. The couple had run an education company in Afghanistan for almost two decades.
content: A British couple who spent almost two decades running education programs in Afghanistan were detained by the Taliban earlier this month, their children said in interviews with a number of British news outlets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Muktita Suhartono
title: On Chinese Tuna Boats, North Koreans Trawl for Cash for Kim Jong-un
description: Thousands of miles from home, North Koreans work on Chinese tuna longliners in the Indian Ocean for pay that goes to their leader, a new study says.
content: They spent up to 10 years at sea, toiling in some of the harshest conditions distant-water fishing crews ​can face. Many never set foot on land because their Chinese captains did not want them to be seen by the port authorities. Most of their salaries went directly to their government, and some of their catch has likely ended up on dining tables in Europe and Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle, Nicholas Nehamas, Madeleine Ngo and Karoun Demirjian
title: Fake Video of Trump and Musk Appears on TVs at Housing Agency
description: The video, which appeared to be generated by artificial intelligence, was emblazoned with the message “Long Live the Real King.”
content: Monitors at the Washington, D.C., headquarters of the Department of Housing and Urban Development on Monday briefly displayed a fake video depicting President Trump sucking the toes of Elon Musk, according to department employees and others familiar with what transpired. The video, which appeared to be generated by artificial intelligence, was emblazoned with the message “Long Live the Real King.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Alberto Rodriguez and Carlos Nazario
title: Fashion That Lasts for Generations
description: For spring, designers are embracing the elegance of timeless, uniform-inspired clothes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: enunciation
description: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word enunciation has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 14 in “‘King Lear,’ Faster and Less Furious.” The review, written by Maya Phillips, includes a critique of Kenneth Branagh’s acting:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘Zero Day’ Is a Throwback Thriller With Modern Echoes
description: The new Netflix series is a contemporary update of a ’70s-style political drama that is even more contemporary than its creators anticipated.
content: The new Netflix limited series “Zero Day” has been in development for several years, but it is arriving at a time when its primary themes — regarding presidential overreach, the hacking of the federal government and the persistence of disinformation — are dominating the actual news cycle. It is a contemporary update of a ’70s-style political drama that is even more contemporary than anticipated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Historic Black Newspaper Gets a Museum
description: The New York Amsterdam News, which was founded 115 years ago and has published civil rights leaders, will convert most of its Harlem building into a museum and community space.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a museum that celebrates the way a newspaper in Harlem used to be written and edited. We’ll also get details on New York State’s decision to cut off funding to two private Hasidic Jewish schools in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Met Museum Returning Ancient Bronze Thought Stolen from Greek Museum
description: The head of a griffin from 7th century B.C. is believed to have been taken from a museum in Olympia in the 1930s and later sold on the art market.
content: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is returning to Greece the bronze head of a griffin, the mythological creature, after determining that the artifact from the 7th century B.C. was likely stolen from an archaeological museum in Olympia in the 1930s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Gibbs, Fred T. Goldberg Jr., Charles Rossotti, Mark Everson, John Koskinen, Charles Rettig and Daniel Werfel
title: Trump Just Fired 6,700 I.R.S. Workers in the Middle of Tax Season. That’s a Huge Mistake.
description: The Trump administration’s decision to fire over 6,000 I.R.S. workers will make the government less effective and less efficient, not more.
content: If you were to ask the top chief executives in the world to name the best strategy to attack waste in their organizations and balance the books, there is one answer you would be very, very unlikely to hear: Take an ax to accounts receivable, the part of an organization responsible for collecting revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Pentagon Purge, and the Danger Ahead
description: Readers discuss the dismissal of military leaders. Also: A refusal to obey; the Supreme Court’s dilemma; students with disabilities; company profits; tenderness.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should Men Wear White Jeans?
description: Our critic explains why Frenchmen love crisp denim, and what you can learn from them about how to style these statement pants without looking too contrived — on either side of Labor Day.
content: You clearly have not been watching the back catalog of French New Wave movies. Onscreen, Jean-Paul Belmondo and Alain Delon are practically poster boys for men in white jeans, especially on the Riviera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: A Discovery of Lost Pages Brings to Light a ‘Last Great Yiddish Novel’
description: Editors waited decades for the final manuscript of Chaim Grade’s “Sons and Daughters.” Its appearance shook the Yiddish literary world.
content: Altie Karper had been waiting for the call for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tatiana Firsova and Jim Tankersley
title: How TikTok Helped the Far Left Surprise in Germany
description: Struggling a month ago, the Die Linke party surged into Parliament by riding a backlash against conservative immigration policy.
content: Her fans call her Heidi. She is 36 years old. She talks a mile a minute. She has a tattoo of the Polish-German revolutionary Rosa Luxemburg on her left arm and a million followers across TikTok and Instagram. She was relatively unknown in German politics until January, but as of Sunday, she’s a political force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: These 5 Books Might Make You a Better Friend
description: Counselors, researchers and health professionals share the titles they recommend the most.
content: Emely Rumble, a therapist in New York City who brings literature into her practice, knows that reading can help people reflect on their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas J. R. White and Kat Hill
title: Take a Look: A Dark Scottish Isle Where Starlight Reigns Supreme
description: On Rum, Europe’s newest dark-sky sanctuary, the island’s 40 residents have learned to embrace darkness.
content: Rum, a diamond-shaped island off the western coast of Scotland, is home to 40 people. Most of the island — 40 square miles of mountains, peatland and heath — is a national nature reserve, with residents mainly nestled around Kinloch Bay to the east. What the Isle of Rum lacks is artificial illumination. There are no streetlights, light-flooded sports fields, neon signs, industrial sites or anything else casting a glow against the night sky. On a cold January day, the sun sets early and rises late, yielding to a blackness that envelopes the island, a blackness so deep that the light of stars manifests suddenly at dusk and the glow of the moon is bright enough to navigate by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Roberta Flack, Virtuoso Singer-Pianist Who Ruled the Charts, Dies at 88
description: With majestic anthems like “Killing Me Softly” and “The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face,” Ms. Flack, a former schoolteacher, became one of the most widely heard artists of the 1970s.
content: Roberta Flack, the magnetic singer and pianist whose intimate blend of soul, jazz and folk made her one of the most popular artists of the 1970s, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Justices Appear Narrowly Divided Over Death Row Prisoner Plea for DNA Testing
description: The justices heard arguments in the case of a man on death row in Texas who claims DNA testing could spare his life.
content: Ruben Gutierrez, a Texas death row inmate, says that newly uncovered DNA evidence proves that he did not stab an 85-year-old woman to death inside her mobile home more than two decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Joann, 80-Year-Old Crafts and Fabrics Retailer, Will Close All Stores
description: The announcement that the chain would close all 800 of its stores in 49 states comes after a period of financial turmoil.
content: Joann, the fabrics and crafts retailer that has supplied quilters, seamstresses and school projects for 80 years, announced that it would close down all of its stores in the latest chapter of financial tumult for the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.5 Million Homes in California
description: An Italianate house in San Francisco, a contemporary house on 42 acres in Carmel Valley and a post-and-beam house in Santa Barbara.
content: This four-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bathroom house is in the Mission District, half a mile from Mission Dolores Park and within walking distance of a movie theater, the Tartine Bakery and numerous coffee shops and bars. The sellers’ renovations began in 2017, resulting in new tile, wallpaper, plumbing, electrical and HVAC systems, and an expanded lower level with a full bedroom and bathroom. Much original millwork is in good condition, and several chandeliers are original too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Kendall
title: America Has a Rogue President
description: The firing of three judge advocate generals is one more element of this administration’s attack on the rule of law.
content: President Trump’s decision to fire senior military leaders without cause is foolish and a disgrace. It politicizes our professional military in a dangerous and debilitating way. What frightens me even more is the removal of three judge advocates general, the most senior uniformed legal authorities in the Defense Department. Their removal is one more element of this administration’s attack on the rule of law, and an especially disturbing part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Jim Tankersley
title: 5 Takeaways From Germany’s Election
description: Friedrich Merz and his party won, Elon Musk didn’t seem to move voters, and more lessons from an early German vote with big implications for Europe.
content: Germany is getting a new chancellor. Its current leader is heading out of power, but his party probably will stick around in a diminished capacity. And the Trump administration’s efforts to influence the vote don’t seem to have done much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Meaning of Germany’s Election
description: We examine the role of immigration in the outcome.
content: Germany yesterday became the latest country where voters rejected a left-leaning government largely because of their unhappiness over immigration and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Hamas Official Expresses Reservations About Oct. 7 Attack on Israel
description: Mousa Abu Marzouk, the head of Hamas’s foreign relations office, said he would not have supported such an attack on Israel had he known of the devastation it would wreak on Gaza.
content: For months, leaders of Hamas have defended the militant group’s decision to launch the Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel, even though it ignited a devastating Israeli offensive that has killed tens of thousands of Palestinians in Gaza and reduced the territory to rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Jim Tankersley
title: Republicans Face Backlash, and the Dangers of Fake A.I. Therapists
description: Plus, is the daytime soap opera back?
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Delta Flight Makes Emergency Landing After ‘Possible Smoke’ in Plane, F.A.A. Says
description: Flight 876 returned to Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport on Monday after the crew reported seeing haze in the flight deck.
content: A Delta Air Lines flight returned to Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport on Monday morning after the crew reported “possible smoke” inside the aircraft, prompting the pilot to declare an emergency and passengers to evacuate by slides once it safely landed, the airline and federal officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Johnson
title: 16 Cheap, Healthy Dinners for When You’re All Out of Ideas
description: Let us make the decisions for you.
content: Eating with budget in mind might feel more difficult than ever these days, when talk of egg prices and tariffs permeate the general conversation. Add in the need to make meals nutritionally balanced, and the whole thing quickly becomes overwhelming. Don’t stress. Let the 16 recipes below remind you that it’s totally possible to cook a budget-friendly, nutritious meal that’s, above all, delicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Judge Declines to Immediately Restore A.P.’s Access to Trump Events
description: But the judge hinted that future rulings in the suit could go differently, cautioning the White House to “think about whether what they’re doing is really appropriate.”
content: A federal judge cleared the way on Monday for the White House to continue barring The Associated Press from covering news events with President Trump, extending a legal fight over freedom of speech and press access, which Mr. Trump has long sought to challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Star Maestro, Facing Recurrence of Brain Cancer, Scales Back Concerts
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, who led the San Francisco Symphony for 25 years, said, “Now is the time to wind down my public appearances.”
content: The renowned conductor Michael Tilson Thomas announced on Monday that he would scale back his engagements because of a recurrence of brain cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Greenpeace Goes to Court in $300 Million Suit That Poses Bankruptcy Risk
description: In a closely watched case, the owner of the Dakota Access Pipeline is claiming the environmental group masterminded protests that hurt the company’s business.
content: Greenpeace went on trial on Monday in North Dakota in a bombshell lawsuit that, if successful, could bankrupt the storied group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Schaefer
title: Making Dancers Fly, Hooked to a Tree or Soaring Off a Cliff
description: For the Oakland dance troupe Bandaloop every surface is a stage. Now its vertical choreography and environmental ethos have come to Broadway in “Redwood.”
content: In 1990, Amelia Rudolph was hiking through Tuolumne Meadows, a stunning mountain pass in Yosemite National Park, when she had an epiphany on a shiny granite bluff: “Could you make a performance here?” she wondered. “Could you dance on a cliff?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger
title: Europe Prepares to Face Russia as Trump’s America Steps Back
description: European leaders visited Kyiv to mark the war’s third anniversary. The show of solidarity in Ukraine on Monday comes at a head-spinning moment for the continent.
content: President Trump was barely acknowledged in a meeting between President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and 13 Western leaders who visited Kyiv in person on Monday to mark the third anniversary of Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Zelensky Sets Somber Tone as Ukraine Marks War Anniversary
description: For Ukrainians, Feb. 24 was a day to remember, without major ceremony, what has been lost in the three years since Russia’s full-scale invasion.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine set a somber tone on Monday for the third anniversary of Russia’s invasion, posting a short video praising Ukrainians for their sacrifices and honoring those who died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: For a Mother and Son, Life Above a Brooklyn Library
description: When Miguelina Minier heard that her local library was being renovated with affordable housing added on top, she applied. It was about the 40th time she had tried a housing lottery.
content: Ian Avilez can’t get enough of books. So much so that the first-grader is reading at a third-grade level. “I used to read to him when he was a baby,” said his mother, Miguelina Minier. His kindergarten teacher asked about Ian’s expansive vocabulary. “Why does Ian know words that I didn’t even teach him?’ I’m like, ‘We live on top of the library,’” Ms. Minier said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: The Ukraine War’s 3rd Anniversary
description: Plus, letting resorts run wild.
content: President Trump met with President Emmanuel Macron of France at the White House yesterday at a head-spinning time for Western alliances. It was the third anniversary of the war in Ukraine, and peace talks with Russia have sidelined Kyiv and European leaders. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: French Doctor Accused of Abusing Hundreds Acknowledges ‘Heinous Acts’
description: A former surgeon is accused of raping or sexually assaulting 299 people, mostly children, over 25 years. It is considered to be France’s largest-ever pedophilia case.
content: A former surgeon went on trial in western France on Monday on charges that he raped or sexually assaulted hundreds of people, most of them former pediatric patients, in what is widely considered the biggest pedophilia case in French history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: An Important Judicial Tool Mysteriously Goes Missing at the Supreme Court
description: The justices have all but stopped issuing summary reversals, which are unsigned decisions used to correct clear errors by lower courts.
content: When the Supreme Court ruled last month in favor of a woman sent to death row in Oklahoma based on lurid sexual evidence, it used a judicial tool that was once commonplace but has all but disappeared in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Hopes Fade for Workers Trapped for Days in Tunnel in India
description: Local officials have been unable to make contact with eight people after wall of silt and water caused the ceiling to collapse.
content: Indian officials have warned that the chances of survival for eight people believed to have been trapped in a collapsed tunnel for several days are remote, after a rush of silt and water caused the ceiling to cave in over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: What Trump’s Deportation Plans Mean for Central America
description: Deporting migrants to Central American countries removes many political and legal hurdles for the Trump administration. How far can the practice go before these nations reach a breaking point?
content: Central American countries have long taken back their own citizens deported from the United States. But now the Trump administration has called on them to take in people from other countries around the world as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: In One Woman’s Life, the Story of Ukraine’s War, 3 Years On
description: In treatment for cancer and with her husband in a Russian prison, Olha Kurtmallaieva, 25, worries that time may be running out for her and, possibly, her country.
content: In the years since her husband was captured by the Russians, Olha Kurtmallaieva has done whatever she could to speed his return. She has organized rallies to support prisoners of war, pleaded with government officials and read books to understand the psychological trauma that her husband is likely to experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: 6 Takeaways From Alec and Hilaria Baldwin’s TLC Reality Show
description: The series begins just before he was scheduled to stand trial in the fatal shooting on the set of “Rust.” The reviews have been somewhat uneasy.
content: Reality television producers had been circling Alec and Hilaria Baldwin for years. His Hollywood fame and history of public combustibility, her social media following and their many children and pets were all classic ingredients for a slice-of-life series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How Can I Lower My Climate Risk When Buying a House?
description: The danger from extreme weather is growing, and so are insurance costs. Here’s what to know.
content: A question we get from readers more and more is some version of this: How should the growing risks from climate change affect my decision to buy a house? Or, if I buy a house, where should I buy, and what should I keep in mind?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ten Things I Don’t Want to Hate About You
description: A father and son try to mend a rift between them in a very unusual way.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mehr Singh
title: Will It Crab Rangoon?
description: The Chinese American restaurant staple is so beloved among American chefs that it’s appearing in bagels, on pizza and even in doughnuts.
content: During the first two days Sidedoor Bagel in Indianapolis sold its Mr. Krabs Rangoon special — crab-flecked cream cheese and a fried egg inside a spicy everything bagel studded with Sichuan pepper flakes, sweet chile sauce and wonton strips — there were more than 100 orders, making it the shop’s most popular special to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Singular Charm of Parker Posey
description: For years, the "indie queen” has had trouble finding satisfying work in Hollywood’s shifting landscape. Then, along came “The White Lotus.”
content: One January morning, I arrived at the East Village studio of a “sound facilitator,” prepared to heal. The facilitator introduced himself as Gary. He led me past a refrigerator cloaked in an Indian tapestry and into an emptied living room, where I found Parker Posey perched cross-legged on a mat, facing a row of gongs. She appeared cozy and at ease, as if she had known the gongs for many years. Posey had invited me there to experience a sound bath, a New Age therapy that she first tried in Thailand, where she filmed the third season of the HBO anthology series “The White Lotus.” During a sound bath (according to Gary’s website), various chimes and bowls are played in an intentional therapeutic sequence; the treatment may uplift the spirit, release stuck energies and rouse engagement with the surrounding environment. Or it may not, but Gary seemed nice anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva
title: Russian Officials Mark Ukraine War Anniversary With Resounding Silence
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is not scheduled to attend any events on Monday to mark the anniversary of the full-scale invasion that he ordered.
content: No public events. No speeches, memorial church services for fallen soldiers or mentions on state television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin, Tripp Mickle and Jason Karaian
title: Apple Vows to Build A.I. Servers in Houston and Spend $500 Billion in U.S.
description: The company pledged the multibillion-dollar investment over the next four years and said it would create 20,000 jobs. The Texas facility is set to open in 2026.
content: Days after Apple’s chief executive met with President Trump, the company said on Monday that it planned to spend $500 billion and hire 20,000 people in the United States over the next four years and open a factory in Texas to make the machines that power the company’s push into artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Doll
title: Curtis Sittenfeld’s New Stories Revel in Life’s Delicious Mess
description: Her story collection is about the thorny conundrums of being alive.
content: There seems to be a largely held belief (one easily argued against, and yet, it persists) that at some point in our lives, perhaps around middle age, whenever that is, we’ll have figured it all out. We will have accrued the proper things to make ourselves at least reasonably content (relationships, jobs, homes, children; all the stuff that makes a life); we will have done the due diligence of coming to terms with who we are, and we will forge ahead, no more questions asked, for all has been settled. Done and dusted; there’s nothing to see here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: In an Age of Right-Wing Populism, Why Are Denmark’s Liberals Winning?
description: Around the world, progressive parties have come to see tight immigration restrictions as unnecessary, even cruel. What if they’re actually the only way for progressivism to flourish?
content: Mette Frederiksen, the prime minister of Denmark, had returned from Ukraine hours earlier and was munching on a baby carrot when I walked into her office on a recent Wednesday afternoon. She laughed as she finished the carrot, evidently not expecting a visitor quite yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,347
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Musk Calls to Congratulate Leader of German Hard-Right Party
description: The leader of the party said she received the call after the party known as the AfD finished second in national elections, by far the best showing in its history.
content: The hard-right Alternative for Germany might not have done as well in Sunday’s election as its leaders had hoped, but its groundbreaking performance was enough for a congratulatory phone call from Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trump, Again, Chooses Loyalty Over Leadership
description: The firing of the nation’s top military officer is the latest example of the president prioritizing fealty over sound policy and expertise.
content: In an era that demands stable, experienced leadership, President Trump’s decision Friday to remove Gen. Charles Q. Brown as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff — alongside other military firings and a series of contentious cabinet appointments — underscored once again an alarming preference for loyalty over expertise. This shift doesn’t just undermine the future of policy and governance; it destabilizes the very foundation of the institutions that have long safeguarded America’s democracy and substitutes politics for professionalism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Makes a Good Red-Carpet Host?
description: Lilly Singh caught some flak for what online critics called cringey interviews before the Screen Actors Guild Awards ceremony. The job may be tougher than it looks.
content: Being a red-carpet host doesn’t sound so bad: just wear something spangly and chat with celebrities on their way into an awards show. Ask a few questions, ideally ones that let actors plug the brands that dressed them, and send them off to collect their trophies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Farmers Sue Over Deletion of Climate Data From Government Websites
description: The data, which disappeared from Agriculture Department sites in recent weeks, was useful to farmers for business planning, the lawsuit said.
content: Organic farmers and environmental groups sued the Agriculture Department on Monday over its scrubbing of references to climate change from its website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martín González Gómez, Ilana Marcus, Jasmine C. Lee, Christopher F. Schuetze, Josh Holder and Agnes Chang
title: Germany Election Maps: How Conservatives Regained Power
description: Maps show how every district in Germany voted. The conservative Christian Democrats have won the most seats while the far-right AfD placed second.
content: Maps show how every district in Germany voted. The conservative Christian Democrats have won the most seats while the far-right AfD placed second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Popular Books That Were Adapted for the Screen?
description: Try this short quiz that highlights the film or television adaptations of novels and memoirs that often have a sharp comic edge.

title: Tracking Tropical Cyclone Alfred

author: By Katherine Miller and Margie Omero
title: How 12 Americans See Life After Watching a Lot of TikTok
description: People who use TikTok daily talk about why they love the app, how consuming and addicting social media can be and why they wouldn’t want their kids to use it.

author: By Christina Kelso
title: Fake Video of Trump Sucking Musk’s Toes Plays at HUD Headquarters
description: A fake video depicting President Trump sucking on the toes of the tech billionaire Elon Musk played on monitors in the headquarters of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The video appeared to be generated by artificial intelligence.
content: A fake video depicting President Trump sucking on the toes of the tech billionaire Elon Musk played on monitors in the headquarters of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. The video appeared to be generated by artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Hicks, Christina Thornell, Rebecca Suner, Gaëlle Girbes and David Jouppi
title: 5 Photos Show How the Ukraine War Changed
description: On the third anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Tyler Hicks, a war photographer for The New York Times, looks back at five photos he took during the conflict and reflects on how the rules of engagement have changed, affecting what he can document and what the world can witness.
content: On the third anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Tyler Hicks, a war photographer for The New York Times, looks back at five photos he took during the conflict and reflects on how the rules of engagement have changed, affecting what he can document and what the world can witness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley, Nikolay Nikolov and James Surdam
title: Who Is Friedrich Merz, Germany’s Likely New Chancellor?
description: After an election dominated by immigration and economic issues, Germany’s likely new chancellor is Friedrich Merz, the leader of the conservative Christian Democrats. His party finished first with just under 29 percent of the vote and will need to form a coalition government.
content: After an election dominated by immigration and economic issues, Germany’s likely new chancellor is Friedrich Merz, the leader of the conservative Christian Democrats. His party finished first with just under 29 percent of the vote and will need to form a coalition government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Roberta Flack, ‘Killing Me Softly’ Singer, Dies at 88
description: As a Grammy Award-winning singer and pianist, Roberta Flack topped the charts as one of the most popular artists of the 1970s.
content: As a Grammy Award-winning singer and pianist, Roberta Flack topped the charts as one of the most popular artists of the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Thielking and Theodore Tae
title: Bird Flu Is Spreading. Are Eggs Safe?
description: Is it safe to eat eggs right now? Yes — but Megan Thielking, a Well editor, details a few things to know.
content: Is it safe to eat eggs right now? Yes — but Megan Thielking, a Well editor, details a few things to know.

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Friedrich Merz Is Set to Be Germany’s Next Chancellor
description: The leader of the conservative Christian Democrats celebrated as exit polls indicated they had won Sunday’s election, which had the highest voter turnout in decades.
content: The leader of the conservative Christian Democrats celebrated as exit polls indicated they had won Sunday’s election, which had the highest voter turnout in decades.
